Jun 30, 2016

The Knicks Wall’s 2016 New York Knicks Offseason/Free Agency Primer

The 2016 offseason is upon us and we have the answers to your many questions.

The 2015–16 NBA season is officially in the books. The Knicks missed the playoffs for the third season in a row, and despite some positive signs to start the year, they ultimately ended up leaving a bad taste in the mouth of fans.

Shocking, I know.

This offseason represents a big opportunity for the Knickerbockers. They have some money to play with, gaining cap space after the Derrick Rose trade and after both Arron Afflalo and Derrick Williams chose to explore free agency. All signs are pointing towards Joakim Noah being a Knick, so that has to be accounted for. I’ll talk more about that below.

They could decide to sign players for just this season to preserve long term cap space, or they could take advantage of their flexibility and lock guys in for the foreseeable future.

After the Noah signing, it seems like they are planning on utilizing the cap space that they have for this offseason. Management clearly wants to become competitive as quick as they possibly can. For a sport like basketball, where a single star player can be the difference between being a lottery team to a fringe playoff team to a championship team, evaluating the offseason correctly is huge. The Knicks are no different. With no further ado, let’s dive in.

Cap Situation

I started drafting this article when the Knicks still had Robin Lopez and Williams/Afflalo hadn’t yet decided on their options. The Joakim Noah news also muddies the water a bit. Safe to say that the sheet looks a little different than it did just a couple weeks ago. Talk of expansion of the salary cap in the NBA has been bubbling under the surface for years now, with a spanking new TV deal the main reason for the boost. Naturally, this means that all 30 teams will have more money to spend in free agency. The Knicks’ cap sheet for the 2016–17 season looks like this, sans the likely Noah signing:

Man, that is a short list. Accounting for the cap holds of their pending free agents, the Knicks will have around $29 million to dip into free agency. If they renounce their rights to those guys, they will have about $34 million.

After this season, Porzingis, Anthony, and O’Quinn represent the only three players under contract. All of this is pre-Joakim. With the salary cap reaching an eye-popping $94 million this offseason, and poised to push the $110 million mark the following year, the Knicks have a ton of flexibility and a ton of spending power moving forward. Does that scare you? It might, but in the same way that a roller coaster is scary. You can’t really control what happens, you’re just along for the ride.

Pending Free Agents: Who (If Any) Will Be Back?

  • Arron Afflalo (UFA): Afflalo had a decent enough year for the Knicks last year. I think he was about what everyone expected. Something about him just sours after a while. I enjoyed watching him for the first third of the season or so, but as time went on, I found myself groaning at him a ton. He was upset when he got benched last year, and apparently still thinks he’s a premier shooting guard in this league. Okay, boss. See ya never. OUT.
  • Derrick Williams (UFA): Has Williams sorta shed the bust label? Probably not, but he had a good year last year, posting career highs in shooting percentage and PER. If he gets offered significantly more than his previous contract, though, I think the Knicks should let him walk. He’s athletic yet a poor defender, and had some pretty atrocious on/off splits. At the right price, he can be a good guy off the bench to bring some energy (remember this?). He’s a bit of a toss up in my mind. If you put me on the spot, I’d say he leaves. OUT.
  • Kevin Seraphin (UFA): A replaceable bench big. The frontcourt shouldn’t be a huge problem for the Knicks. Willy Hernangomez is ready to come to the NBA, and he’s going to need some minutes. Seraphin should walk. OUT.
  • Lou Amundson (UFA): Another replaceable guy at the end of the bench. As a 15th guy, sure, he can come back to New York. Not a big deal either way. OUT.
  • Lance Thomas (UFA): Phil Jackson has said that he anticipates resigning both Thomas and Galloway, but this was last week, so his tune could change once free agency opens. The contracts that guys like Thomas receive will be intriguing to follow. With the cap increase, all of the numbers are going to go through the roof. While the Knicks would like to have Thomas back, he is getting interest from around the league, and I think Jackson may be hard-pressed to bring him back. However, I think the Knicks really loved what they saw from him last year, so I think he ends up back in New York. IN.
  • Sasha Vujacic (UFA): Great teammate, nice dude, but no. No. No? No. OUT.
  • Cleanthony Early (UFA): The Knicks neglected to give Early a qualifying offer, making him an unrestricted free agent. He is playing with the Knicks during the summer league once again, and they hoping he can gain some much needed confidence in his jumper. He’s going to have to earn his spot this season. The allure of him being a star in college has faded, and his potential in the NBA is murky at best. The team would love him to come into the summer league and play well, but it’s far from a guarantee. His spot on the roster may depend on how they deal with free agency. IN (the D-League).
  • Langston Galloway (RFA): The Knicks extended a qualifying offer to Galloway on Thursday, which made him a restricted free agent. I’d be surprised if Galloway doesn’t return. Teams can offer him a big raise in the third year of a potential deal, which could be a threat, but I think the Knicks have high hopes for him moving forward. He’s got potential to be a knockdown shooter, as he was setting the world on fire during the first several games last year. Hitting those shots at a consistent clip will be essential for his development. IN.

Summer League

The Knicks are switching over to the Orlando summer league this year after playing in the Las Vegas summer league since 2005. They kick off the abbreviated season on July 2. Here’s the lineup they’ll be trotting out:

Some names should stick out on there. Here’s a quick rundown:

  • Ron Baker and Cleanthony Early of past Wichita State greatness are reuniting on a much smaller stage. Baker signed a partially guaranteed deal immediately after the draft, so he will be a guy that they feature. These two will probably be your leading scorers.
  • You may recognize the name Louis Labeyrie. He was a second round pick of the Pacers in 2014, and immediately had his rights traded to New York. He’s a defender that can rebound, but his offensive game leaves a lot to be desired. He’s not an NBA talent, but it’s always cool to see a draft pick play in the summer league.
  • Marshall Plumlee is the youngest Plum, siblings with Marshall and Miles. Like his brothers, he is a behemoth of a human being. Not sure if he has any sort of future because of his general lack of skill, but hey, PLUMS!!!
  • It should be cool to see Jeff Hornacek coach this team. I would bet that they’ll play at a decently high pace and shoot a good amount of threes in an attempt to test out his coaching style while maintaining some triangle aspects. Anything to make the summer league more interesting, guys.
  • That’s Devin Booker, MVP of the LNB Pro A league in France. Not Devin Booker, young stud of the Phoenix Suns. Maybe if they switch spots, no one will notice? Please?
  • College basketball fans may recognize J.P. Tokoto from his time as a Tar Heel. He can’t really shoot and is undersized, so he doesn’t bring a ton to the table.

The Kevin Durant Question

Let’s make this quick, shall we? Kevin Durant is absolutely, unequivocally, irrefutably not coming to New York. The Noah signing would be the final nail in the coffin. It was always a pipe dream. The big markets aren’t as attractive to these guys anymore since they can become stars in smaller cities (see: KD, Stephen Curry, Damian Lillard, etc). The words “New York” and “Madison Square Garden” still carry weight, but they don’t place a twinkle in the eye of free agents. While Durant and Carmelo Anthony may be buddies, and he favorably compared Kristaps Porzingis to a mythical figure, it’s not happening. I don’t want to hear it. Just stop. Enough negativity, back to the fun!

Five Free Agents to Keep an Eye On

There’s been a ton of speculation regarding whom the Knicks will target in the offseason, but I’m going to take a look at a couple guys that have been talked about a lot, and a couple that I personally like.

Joakim Noah

After spending nine seasons in Chicago, the Knicks have emerged as the strong favorite to land Noah. It’s looking like he will be in line for about $18 million per year, but the full terms of a potential deal have yet to be announced. Noah struggled with injuries last season, as he managed to only play 29 games. He was pretty ineffective in those 29 games, shooting a horrid 38.3% while averaging just 4.3 points per game. His injuries from last year are a concern in the sense that he is getting older, but all signs point toward shim being healthy for this coming year.

Some fans are understandably apprehensive about signing a guy that looks to be on the decline to a big money deal. I would tend to agree that I don’t want to see him signed for four years, but I think it’s the most likely option. I have no information on that, just my gut.

It’s important to remember that this summer is going to be INSANE. Dudes that aren’t associated with big contracts like Kent Bazemore and Marvin Williams are going to demand some serious cash. The always excellent Tommy Beer points out that Noah’s deal has to be looked at in terms of this year’s salary cap:

Here’s the way to look at the Noah deal: Robin Lopez is making $13–$14 million annually. Let’s say Noah makes exactly $18 million. We need to look at all of these new contracts as a percentage of the cap rather than a dollar figure until we adjust to the new inflated salary cap. While Lopez’s contract will look better with the salary cap increase, when looking through a lens of relativity, the deals are comparable.

A healthy Noah is a better player than Lopez. This is a fact. He will be a great fit next to Porzingis, and has always had a knack for dishing from the pivot. RoLo is a better rim protector than Noah, but Joakim can defend the pick and roll with the best of them thanks to his mobility. It’s going to be difficult to effectively evaluate this deal until the full details come out, but in terms of fit, I think a healthy, active, boisterous Noah is the glass slipper to the Knicks’ Cinderella.

Courtney Lee

Since the Knicks seemed to have found their center, addressing the shooting guard position has quickly shot to the top of their priorities. A career 38.4% three point shooter, Lee would fill a need for the Knicks while also representing an option cheaper than some others currently on the market. He has a reputation as a solid defender and would be a good guy to have spotting up on the perimeter. Additionally, his track record as an NBA veteran is well established at this point, and the Knicks could use some durable, reliable players on the roster.

Having a two guard that can knock down the three is important enough in today’s NBA. Next to a slasher like Derrick Rose, it is an absolute necessity. Plain and simple. Three and D players have found their niche in the NBA, and as a result, have landed some decent cash in free agency (DeMarre Carroll? Andre Iguodala? Iman Shumpert?). Lee has been around forever, but it hasn’t been until now that his true value has been appreciated. The Knicks have been linked to Lee, and would do good to ink him to a deal.

Eric Gordon

Another guard that has been linked to the Knicks over the past few days is the injury prone centerpiece of the now almost five year old Chris Paul trade, Eric Gordon. Like Lee, Gordon is a good three point shooter, hitting at a 38.3% clip for his career. He’s also managed to pour in 16.6 points per game for his career. It feels like forever ago when he was a young stud averaging over 20 points for the Clippers, so he may even be a little underrated nowadays. While this is all well and good, there’s a clear reason why he has lost steam in some circles.

This dude cannot stay on the floor. He has missed a total of 173 games over the past five seasons. From knee to shoulder to wrist, he has been banged up during every season since he left Los Angeles. Name a body part, he’s probably injured it. The notoriously injury prone Rose is impressed with Gordon’s track record.

Signing him and putting him next to Rose, Noah, and Anthony, who have all had their fair share of injuries over the past couple years, would be risky. Lee is the safer option, but a healthy Gordon could give Derrick Rose a more effective partner in the backcourt. It’s just a hunch, but I think Gordon could command a little more money than Lee (bold), while receiving a shorter term deal (not so bold). If the Knicks are looking to contend (I suppose we’re at that point now? Man, life comes at you fast), Lee is a good guy to lock in for three years at a reasonable price. The upside with Gordon may be too tantalizing for Phil to ignore, however. The market will likely define the price tag for these guys quickly, in which case the picture will become more vivid. I prefer Lee, but a one year Gordon signing would not be the worst thing.

Lance Stephenson

I know, I know. I think I threw up a little in my mouth just from finding the picture online and writing his name in the title. But hear me out.

Stephenson played reasonably well after making his way to Memphis mid-season last year. He’s not much of a shooter, but he is an above average finisher at the hoop, shooting 65.7% within 3 feet for his career (3–4 percentage points better than league average). His reputation across the league was always tenuous, but his flame out in Charlotte cemented his status as a punchline. We’re now two years removed from that. He went to high school in New York and the Knicks could use some weapons off of the bench. It’s not ideal, but I think he’s worth a flier. Reclamation projects are inherently risky, but if the Knicks could land Stephenson on a relatively cheap one year pact, it could pay off in spades if he resembles the artist known as “Born Ready”.

Dwight Howard

Just kidding.

E’Twaun Moore

Moore backed up Rose last year in Chicago, and had easily the best season of his career. He started 22 games and set career highs in shooting percentages (45.2% from three and 48.1% from the field). There are better options out there for a backup guard, including Tyler Johnson and Matthew Dellavedova, but they are restricted free agents. The kind of money that they will get on the open market isn’t clear, but the restricted free agency makes me a little skeptical. You may think that Moore will come super cheap, but after filling in adequately for the Bulls last year, he could command $5-$6 million. Zach Lowe talked about him in an article from earlier today (I thought he would be a good fit before I read the article, I swear!):

Moore is ideally a bigger version of Patrick Beverley, a guy who defends opposing point guards and spots up on offense while a ball-dominant wing such as Butler does the heavy lifting. He shot a scorching — and unsustainable — 45 percent from deep, feasting on catch-and-shoot looks from the corners and beyond.
He has some craft to his off-the-bounce game, and he needs it. He isn’t explosive enough to get to the rim, so he relies on hesitation dribbles, shoulder shimmies and snakey crossovers to open space for floaters.
He never gets to the line because he almost never gets near the rim. When opponents duck under picks against him, they are generally fast enough to beat Moore to the other side — and wall off Moore’s driving lane before he can get downhill.
It’s harder to loft floaters over wing players, and at 6-foot-4, Moore is at a size deficit against them on the other end. Klay Thompson types can rain fire over him, and bullies can dislodge him on the block.
That’s the downside: Moore can’t quite run point for a functional offense, but he can’t defend other positions against at least some opposing starters. On some nights, Moore’s fine because he’s a rugged, heady defender who works hard.
If he settles in as an above-average 3-point shooter, Moore will be a reliable backup at multiple positions who can start in a pinch.

Having Rose as a point guard is nerve wracking because of his penchant for getting injured. The Knicks need to prioritize the backup guard spot and put serious thought into who will be the best option if Rose goes down with an injury. Whether or not Moore is that guy, it will be important for them to secure a solid contingency plan.

Best of the Rest

Some guys like Allen Crabbe, Kent Bazemore, Evan Turner, Nicolas Batum, Timofey Mozgov, and Evan Fournier have had their names thrown around the rumor mill. With Noah taking up a good chunk of that cap space, some of these guys that are going to command max deals are out of the question. I especially love Batum, but he’ll get a ton of interest on a max deal. The Knicks are going to have to fill out the roster

Conclusion

The Knicks will be active during free agency. That is what happens when you go in with only five players under contract. I believe that we’ll see a couple guys back in New York, while some new, exciting faces start to occupy the Garden. It’s been kind of exhilarating to actually have money to spend during the past two offseasons after being locked into a mediocre roster for five years.

Based on the moves that they have made already, they seem determined to give Carmelo Anthony a real team before he begins to lose the bout with Father Time. If that’s the case, they need to go out and solidify the backcourt.

I’m excited to see what goes down starting at midnight tonight, and it’s going to be a blast to follow.
